ofx:section.ofx:title: Operating System (Debian Linux)
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: Debian is an operating system composed of free software mostly carrying the GNU General Public License. The operating system is developed by an Internet collaboration of volunteers aligned with The Debian Project.

Debian GNU/Linux is one of the most popular Linux distributions for personal computers and network servers. Debian is seen as a stable Linux distribution, and as a consequence has been used as a base for other Linux distributions, there are over 140 active Debian derivatives, one of the most popular ones is Ubuntu.

Since Debian can be used free of charge, it can easily be obtained from the projects website. There is a huge variety of installation methods to choose from. A very convenient one is using the minimum installation CD. You can download the disk image for your architecture (mostly i386 for older 32-bit machines and amd64 for newer 64-bit CPUs like Intel Core processors and above) from http://www.debian.org/distrib/netinst. Then the image needs to be written to a CD or DVD recordable. The Ubuntu project offers HowTos for all common operating systems like Microsoft Windows, Apple Mac OS X and Linux on how to actually burn this image to the disk at https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BurningIsoHowto. Once the CD or DVD is prepared, the computer needs to be booted from the optical disk drive and the (non-graphical) installer should be selected from the boot screen. The Debian installer then guides you through the complete setup process.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Partition disks
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph:
The installation continues with the partition method. Disk partitioning is the act of dividing a hard disk drive (HDD) into multiple logical storage units referred to as partitions, to treat one physical disk drive as if it were multiple disks, so that a different file system can be used on each partition. The total data storage space of a PC HDD can contain at most four primary partitions, or alternatively three primary partitions and an extended partition. A primary partition contains one file system.
Please select "Guided - use entire disk". Now select your HDD and choose "All files in one partition" and go on. After this move finish partitioning and write changes to disk. Check your configuration and confirm it.

ofx:section.ofx:paragraph:

Select your country (or a country with good connection to). Choose a mirror, for example "ftp.(your country).debian.org/debian/". If there is a proxy server in your domain, add the proxy server information and continue. No participation in package usage survey.

ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: All available software packages can be de-selected. This ensures aht the installation will only have a minimal number of packages and modules available. This minimizes the risks of errors or faulty configurations and facilitate future upgrade procedures. Press TAB and select CONTINUE. All necessary packages will be installed manually.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Secure Shell (SSH)
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: The Secure Shell (SSH) is a cryptographic network protocol for secure data communication, remote command-line login, remote command execution, and other secure network services between two networked computers. For this system it is used for the administrator to remotely login to the system and excute shell commands.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Apache
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph:
The Apache HTTP Server is the world's most widely used web server software. Originally based on the NCSA HTTPd server, development of Apache began in early 1995 after work on the NCSA code stalled. Apache played a key role in the initial growth of the World Wide Web, quickly overtaking NCSA HTTPd as the dominant HTTP server, and has remained the most popular HTTP server since April 1996. In 2009, it became the first web server software to serve more than 100 million websites.
Apache is developed and maintained by an open community of developers under the auspices of the Apache Software Foundation. Most commonly used on a Unix-like system (usually Linux), the software is available for a wide variety of operating systems, including Windows, OS X, Linux, Unix, FreeBSD, Solaris, NetWare, OS/2, TPF, OpenVMS and eComStation. Released under the Apache License, Apache is free and open-source software.
As of June 2013, Apache was estimated to serve 54.2% of all active website and 53.3% of the top servers across all domains.

ofx:section.ofx:title: Sudo
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: sudo is a program for Unix-like computer operating systems that allows users to run programs with the security privileges of another user (normally the superuser, or root). Its name is a concatenation of "su" (substitute user) and "do", or take action.

Unlike the su command, users typically supply their own password to sudo rather than the root password. After authentication, and if the /usr/local/etc/sudoers (sometimes found at /etc/sudoers) configuration file permits the user access, then the system will invoke the requested command. The sudoers configuration file enables a huge amount of configurability, including but not limited to: enabling root commands only from the invoking terminal; not requiring a password for certain commands; requiring a password per user or group; requiring re-entry of a password every time or never requiring a password at all for a particular command line. It can also be configured to permit passing arguments or multiple commands, and even supports commands with regular expressions.
